body:
After trying to find a workaround, I could only find that removing ActiveAdmin entirely (initializer and "admin files") would solve the problem.

Reproduction could be achieved with:

```
RAILS_ENV=production bundle exec rake assets:precompile
```

the "heroku labs:enable user-env-compile" workaround worked for me

code that triggers routes loading:
https://github.com/gregbell/active_admin/pull/1910#issuecomment-21304075
For what it's worth, the `user-env-compile` workaround does not work for me. AA still tries, and fails, to connect to the database during precompilation.
+1 - the user-env-compile workaround doesn't work for me neither.
+1 - `user-env-compile` does not work for me.
The monkey-patch described in [this gist](https://gist.github.com/DanielWright/6082147) _does_ work for me. Obviously, YMMV.
I'm currently on vacation, but I'll look into this as soon as I'm back (Tuesday)
Can someone provide steps to reproduce this? Because the loading of your app's routes and the subsequent loading of `app/admin` and `app/models` shouldn't ever cause the database to be hit.

Naively, have you tried the following?
1. Put dummy wrong config in `database.yml` (eg. wrong DB name)
2. Run `rake environment`/`rake assets:precompile`. 

That should raise an error.
To be doubly sure, I just ran `rake db:drop && rake assets:precompile` from inside the test app that AA creates for local development, and still didn't run into any error.
If you're curious, [this is what I'm talking about](https://github.com/gregbell/active_admin/blob/e6721d61f99aa924c7f348168d1ce81c46345a77/CONTRIBUTING.md#5-view-your-changes-in-a-rails-application)

``` ruby
ActiveAdmin.routes(self)

##################################

def routes(rails_router)
   load!

###################################

    def load!
      unless loaded?
        ActiveAdmin::Event.dispatch BeforeLoadEvent, self # before_load hook
        files.each{ |file| load file }                    # load files

######################################################

```

This loads the app\admin files, the register call ends up in:

``` ruby
        def get_primary_key(base_name) #:nodoc:
          return 'id' if base_name.blank?

          case primary_key_prefix_type
          when :table_name
            base_name.foreign_key(false)
          when :table_name_with_underscore
            base_name.foreign_key
          else
            if ActiveRecord::Base != self && table_exists?
              connection.schema_cache.primary_keys(table_name)
            else
              'id'
            end
          end
        end
```

table_exists? and the next line needs a connection
Can you give the full stack trace?

`bundle exec rake --trace RAILS_ENV=production assets:precompile`


Hmm, looks like this is specifically a problem with the PostgreSQL ActiveRecord adapter.

IMO `table_exists?` should not fail if the database doesn't exist. Or perhaps they should provide a `database_exists?` method.

A quick and dirty fix would be:

``` ruby
ActiveAdmin.routes(self) unless ARGV.grep(/assets:precompile/).any?
```

why do you say it's a problem with pg?  The AR methods (table_exists?, get_primary_key) want a connection to get some info from the db.  If the connection can't be established, why wouldn't the adapter raise?  What else can it do?

You may argue that the AR methods should rescue, but assuming they need the connection for a good reason, they would not behave correctly without it, so swallowing the connection exception would not be right.

I would say it makes sense for ActiveAdmin to detect this scenario
While I didn't check the behavior of other DB adapters, e.g. MySQL, the point I was really making is that SQLite does not throw this error, while PostgreSQL does.

Regardless of what's happening with SQLite, it seems fairly obvious that neither AR nor db adapters can quietly handle connection failures.  So the question is, is this a sufficiently common scenario (Heroku deploy) for ActiveAdmin to detect it and work around it.

issue.title: [2342] only build AA routes when necessary

repository.name: activeadmin
repository.description: The administration framework for Ruby on Rails applications.

issue.body:
A possible solution for #2342. With this PR, Active Admin routes are only ever loaded when one of these commands run:

``` sh
rails server
rails console
rake routes
```

If for some reason you want custom control, I've added the `ACTIVE_ADMIN_ROUTING` environment variable.

body: Take a look at #2413 and let me know what you think :octocat:
blacklisting seems safer
What would that blacklist consist of?

considering the removed option was initialize_on_precompile, I would guess you only need to blacklist assets:precompile, or perhaps assets:\* 

With initialize_on_precompile removed, it seems the recommended alternativeis to override assets:environment
https://github.com/rails/sprockets-rails/pull/39
https://github.com/rails/sprockets-rails

``` ruby
Rake::Task['assets:environment'].clear
```

but that's more extreme and could cause other problems, so a more limited workaround in active_admin would still be useful

If that's all that needs to be protected against:

``` ruby
def routes(rails_router)
  return if File.basename($0) == "rake" && ARGV.grep(/assets:precompile/).any?
  load!
  router.apply(rails_router)
end
```

Though IMO there really should be a `database_exists?` method to go along with `table_exists?`. If that could be resolved, no hacks would be necessary.

issue.title: Rails 4 problems

milestone.description:
+ migrates from meta_search to its successor, ransack
+ removes support for Rails < 3.2
+ adds support for Rails 4
+ adds support for Rails 5

repository.name: activeadmin
repository.description: The administration framework for Ruby on Rails applications.

issue.body:
It's time to start working on a version which will work for Rails 4. Because Rails 4 Beta 1 is here finally. Here's the first issue:

``` ruby
Bundler could not find compatible versions for gem "actionpack":
  In Gemfile:
    activeadmin (~> 0.5.1) ruby depends on
      actionpack (~> 3.1) ruby

    rails (= 4.0.0.beta1) ruby depends on
      actionpack (4.0.0.beta1)
```

body:
As a follow-up to the `user-env-compile` discussion earlier in my thread, [my comment](https://github.com/gregbell/active_admin/issues/1963#issuecomment-23094386) posted in #1963 might be illuminating:

> In case anyone's interested, the reason `heroku labs:enable user-env-compile` can resolve this issue is because Heroku stores your instance's `DATABASE_URL` in an eponymous config var, so enabling `user-env-compile` makes `DATABASE_URL` point to an actual database (assuming you're using PostgreSQL), allowing Rails to successfully connect to a database.
> 
> The one gotcha here is provisioning a PostgreSQL addon **is not enough** for Heroku to set the `DATABASE_URL`. You have to successfully deploy and run migrations once. So if you _haven't_ done so and have an ActiveAdmin app you'd like to deploy, `user-env-compile` by itself won't save you. _However_, you can manually set the `DATABASE_URL` config var by copying the `HEROKU_POSTGRESQL_COLOR_URL` config var, which _is_ set when you provision the addon. This will let your app connect to the database backend and allow your deployment to succeed.
> 
> TL;DR:
> 
> `$ heroku labs:enable user-env-compile`
> `$ heroku config:add DATABASE_URL=$(heroku config | awk '/HEROKU_POSTGRESQL.*:/ {print $2}')`
Correct. I've also had success with setting `DATABASE_URL` manually.

Coming back to this, I get the same error (though a different stack trace) when running `rake assets:precompile` when the AA lines are and aren't commented out of `config/routes.rb`

The exact same thing happens when running `rails c`. 

I'm not sure that this is something that Active Admin should be protecting against. More and more, it seems like a problem of the PostgreSQL AR adapter.
